text: today the Dow Jones Industrial Average
plummeted by more than 700 points it was
the biggest one-day drop since September
11th since 2001 as investors centrally
looked at Congress shooting down this
bailout proposal and said my goodness
where's the bottom of this thing the
package seems to fail today because on
the one hand Republicans in the House
are just revolted at the thought of
taking the legacy of Reagan the party
that's supposedly for deregulation and
getting the government out of private
enterprise and directly intervening to
the tune of several hundred billion
dollars in in the banking system
meanwhile you have Democrats saying well
why are we bailing out Wall Street
without doing enough to first of all
give the taxpayer some benefit if these
companies turn around now there are
provisions in this bailout proposal that
do address the concerns that we heard at
the beginning of the process that the
taxpayer gets nothing and that there's
nothing in here for Main Street and
there are now caps for instance on
executive pay there are so-called
warrants essentially if companies do
well companies that take the bailout as
a result the taxpayer will get some of
this stock and we'll be able to sell it
once once fortunes return but there's
still a sense that there's not enough
and Democrats would like to see for
instance a change to the bankruptcy law
so that people who are facing
foreclosure can go into a bankruptcy
court and have a judge actually work out
the terms of their of their loan it's
hard to imagine that the market is going
to calm down until there's a widespread
sense that there is a solution on the
table that there's some certainty here
some sense of you know the map going
forward and until that happens we're
likely to see a lot of volatility
